types.name: Query
types.description: The root Query

fields.name: commentsfor
fields.description:
Comments for a specific object
    
    This query returns all comments for a specific object. The object is
    specified by the `model` and `id` arguments. The `model` argument is
    a string that is the name of the model. The `id` argument is the id of
    the object.

    You can only query for comments for objects that you have access to.

fields.name: experiments
fields.description:
All Experiments 
 ![Image](/static/img/data.png) 
 This query returns all Experiments that are stored on the platform
    depending on the user's permissions. Generally, this query will return
    all Experiments that the user has access to. If the user is an amdin
    or superuser, all Experiments will be returned. 
 If you want to retrieve only the Experiments that you have created,
    use the `myExperiments` query.

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: Comment
types.description:
A comment

A comment is a user generated comment on a commentable object. A comment can be a reply to another comment or a top level comment.
Comments can be nested to any depth. A comment can be edited and deleted by the user that created it.

fields.name: contentType
fields.description: The content type of the commentable object

fields.name: text
fields.description: The text of the comment (without any formatting)

fields.name: descendents
fields.description: The descendents of the comment (this referes to the Comment Tree)

fields.name: children
fields.description: Comments that are replies to this comment

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31 - 1) and 2^31 - 1 since represented in JSON as double-precision floating point numbers specifiedby [IEEE 754](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).

types.name: User
types.description:
User

This object represents a user in the system. Users are used to
control access to different parts of the system. Users are assigned 
to groups. A user has access to a part of the system if the user is
a member of a group that has the permission assigned to it.

Users can be be "creator" of objects. This means that the user has
created the object. This is used to control access to objects. A user
can only access objects that they have created, or objects that they
have access to through a group that they are a member of.

See the documentation for "Object Level Permissions" for more information.

fields.name: groups
fields.description: The groups this user belongs to. A user will get all permissions granted to each of their groups.

fields.name: username
fields.description: Required. 150 characters or fewer. Letters, digits and @/./+/-/_ only.

fields.name: color
fields.description: The prefered color of the user

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the user

types.name: Group
types.description:
Group

This object represents a group in the system. Groups are used to
control access to different parts of the system. Groups are assigned
to users. A user has access to a part of the system if the user is
a member of a group that has the permission assigned to it.

fields.name: userSet
fields.description: The groups this user belongs to. A user will get all permissions granted to each of their groups.

types.name: Permission
types.description:
A Permission object

This object represents a permission in the system. Permissions are
used to control access to different parts of the system. Permissions
are assigned to groups and users. A user has access to a part of the
system if the user is a member of a group that has the permission
assigned to it.

fields.name: userSet
fields.description: Specific permissions for this user.

fields.name: unique
fields.description: Unique ID for this permission

types.name: DateTime
types.description:
The `DateTime` scalar type represents a DateTime
value as specified by
[iso8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601).

types.name: Descendent
types.description: A descendent of a node in the comment tree

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

types.name: SharableModels
types.description: Sharable Models are models that can be shared amongst users and groups. They representent the models of the DB

fields.description: A query that returns an image path

fields.name: group
fields.description: A query that returns an image path

types.name: Experiment
types.description:
An experiment is a collection of samples and their representations.
    It mimics the concept of an experiment in the lab and is the top level
    object in the data model.

    You can use the experiment to group samples and representations likewise
    to how you would group files into folders in a file system.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the experiment

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description of the experiment

fields.name: descriptionLong
fields.description: A long description of the experiment

fields.name: linkedPaper
fields.description: A link to a paper describing the experiment

fields.name: image
fields.description: An image to be used as a banner for the experiment

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The time the experiment was created

fields.name: creator
fields.description: The user that created the experiment

fields.name: pinnedBy
fields.description: The users that have pinned the experiment

fields.name: tags
fields.description: Tags for the experiment

fields.name: omeroFiles
fields.description: The experiment this file belongs to

fields.name: models
fields.description: The experiment this model belongs to

types.name: Representation
types.description:
A Representation is 5-dimensional representation of an image

    Mikro stores each image as sa 5-dimensional representation. The dimensions are:
    - t: time
    - c: channel
    - z: z-stack
    - x: x-dimension
    - y: y-dimension

    This ensures a unified api for all images, regardless of their original dimensions. Another main
    determining factor for a representation is its variety:
    A representation can be a raw image representating voxels (VOXEL)
    or a segmentation mask representing instances of a class. (MASK)
    It can also representate a human perception of the image (RGB) or a human perception of the mask (RGBMASK)

    # Meta

    Meta information is stored in the omero field which gives access to the omero-meta data. Refer to the omero documentation for more information.


    #Origins and Derivations

    Images can be filtered, which means that a new representation is created from the other (original) representations. This new representation is then linked to the original representations. This way, we can always trace back to the original representation.
    Both are encapsulaed in the origins and derived fields.

    Representations belong to *one* sample. Every transaction to our image data is still part of the original acuqistion, so also filtered images are refering back to the sample
    Each iamge has also a name, which is used to identify the image. The name is unique within a sample.
    File and Rois that are used to create images are saved in the file origins and roi origins repectively.

types.name: Table
types.description:
A Table is a collection of tabular data.

    It provides a way to store data in a tabular format and associate it with a Representation,
    Sample or Experiment. It is a way to store data that might be to large to store in a
    Feature or Metric on this Experiments. Or it might be data that is not easily represented
    as a Feature or Metric.

    Tables can be easily created from a pandas DataFrame and can be converted to a pandas DataFrame.
    Its columns are defined by the columns of the DataFrame.

types.name: ROI
types.description:
A ROI is a region of interest in a representation.

    This region is to be regarded as a view on the representation. Depending
    on the implementatoin (type) of the ROI, the view can be constructed
    differently. For example, a rectangular ROI can be constructed by cropping
    the representation according to its 2 vectors. while a polygonal ROI can be constructed by masking the
    representation with the polygon.

    The ROI can also store a name and a description. This is used to display the ROI in the UI.

types.name: PhysicalSize
types.description:
Physical size of the image 

Each dimensions of the image has a physical size. This is the size of the
pixel in the image. The physical size is given in micrometers on a PIXEL
basis. This means that the physical size of the image is the size of the    
pixel in the image * the number of pixels in the image. For example, if 
the image is 1000x1000 pixels and the physical size of the image is 3 (x params) x 3 (y params),
micrometer, the physical size of the image is 3000x3000 micrometer. If the image

The t dimension is given in ms, since the time is given in ms.
The C dimension is given in nm, since the wavelength is given in nm.

types.name: Feature
types.description:
A Feature is a numerical key value pair that is attached to a Label.

    You can model it for example as a key value pair of a class instance of a segmentation mask.
    Representation -> Label0 -> Feature0
                             -> Feature1
                   -> Label1 -> Feature0

    Features can be used to store any numerical value that is attached to a class instance.
    THere can only ever be one key per label. If you want to store multiple values for a key, you can
    store them as a list in the value field.

    Feature are analogous to metrics on a representation, but for a specific class instance (Label)

fields.description: The user that created the Feature

fields.name: key
fields.description: The key of the feature

fields.name: value
fields.description: Value

types.name: FeatureValue
types.description:
A Feature Value

This scalar ensures serializaiton of feature values. Feature values
can be of different types, such as int, float, string, datetime, etc.

However we impose a few rules on the metric values:
- The value must be a scalar
- The value must be a scalar that can be serialized to JSON

A plot is a template to generate a graph

Its store a PlotQL query and a list of variables that can be used in the
query. The variables are stored as a JSON object. The variables are
validated against the query before the query is executed.

This query then returns a graph that can be rendered in the frontend.

fields.name: createComment
fields.description:
Create an Comment 
    
    This mutation creates a comment. It takes a commentable_id and a commentable_type.
    If this is the first comment on the commentable, it will create a new comment thread.
    If there is already a comment thread, it will add the comment to the thread (by setting
    it's parent to the last parent comment in the thread).

    CreateComment takes a list of Descendents, which are the comment tree. The Descendents
    are a recursive structure, where each Descendent can have a list of Descendents as children.
    The Descendents are either a Leaf, which is a text node, or a MentionDescendent, which is a
    reference to another user on the platform.

    Please convert your comment tree to a list of Descendents before sending it to the server.
    TODO: Add a converter from a comment tree to a list of Descendents.

    
    (only signed in users)

args.name: object
args.description: The Representationss this sROI belongs to

args.name: type
args.description: The type model you want to comment on

fields.name: replyTo
fields.description:
Reply to an Comment 
    
    This mutation creates a comment. It takes a commentable_id and a commentable_type.
    If this is the first comment on the commentable, it will create a new comment thread.
    If there is already a comment thread, it will add the comment to the thread (by setting
    it's parent to the last parent comment in the thread).

    CreateComment takes a list of Descendents, which are the comment tree. The Descendents
    are a recursive structure, where each Descendent can have a list of Descendents as children.
    The Descendents are either a Leaf, which is a text node, or a MentionDescendent, which is a
    reference to another user on the platform.

    Please convert your comment tree to a list of Descendents before sending it to the server.
    TODO: Add a converter from a comment tree to a list of Descendents.

    
    (only signed in users)

types.name: OmeroRepresentationInput
types.description:
The Omero Meta Data of an Image

Follows closely the omexml model. With a few alterations:
- The data model of the datasets and experimenters is
part of the mikro datamodel and are not accessed here.
- Some parameters are ommited as they are not really used

types.name: PlaneInput
types.description:
" A plane in an image 

Plane follows the convention of the OME model, where the first index is the
Z axis, the second is the Y axis, the third is the X axis, the fourth is the
C axis, and the fifth is the T axis.

It attached the image at the indicated index to the image and gives information
about the plane (e.g. exposure time, delta t to the origin, etc.)

inputFields.name: z
inputFields.description: Z index of the plane

inputFields.name: y
inputFields.description: Y index of the plane

inputFields.name: x
inputFields.description: X index of the plane

inputFields.name: c
inputFields.description: C index of the plane

inputFields.name: t
inputFields.description: Z index of the plane

inputFields.name: positionX
inputFields.description: The planes X position on the stage of the microscope

inputFields.name: positionY
inputFields.description: The planes Y position on the stage of the microscope

inputFields.name: positionZ
inputFields.description: The planes Z position on the stage of the microscope

inputFields.name: exposureTime
inputFields.description: The exposure time of the plane (e.g. Laser exposure)

inputFields.name: deltaT
inputFields.description: The Delta T to the origin of the image acqusition

types.name: ChannelInput
types.description:
A channel in an image

Channels can be highly variable in their properties. This class is a
representation of the most common properties of a channel.

inputFields.name: name
inputFields.description: The name of the channel

inputFields.name: emmissionWavelength
inputFields.description: The emmission wavelength of the fluorophore in nm

inputFields.name: excitationWavelength
inputFields.description: The excitation wavelength of the fluorophore in nm

inputFields.name: acquisitionMode
inputFields.description: The acquisition mode of the channel

inputFields.name: color
inputFields.description: The default color for the channel (might be ommited by the rendered)

types.name: PhysicalSizeInput
types.description:
Physical size of the image 

Each dimensions of the image has a physical size. This is the size of the
pixel in the image. The physical size is given in micrometers on a PIXEL
basis. This means that the physical size of the image is the size of the    
pixel in the image * the number of pixels in the image. For example, if 
the image is 1000x1000 pixels and the physical size of the image is 3 (x params) x 3 (y params),
micrometer, the physical size of the image is 3000x3000 micrometer. If the image

The t dimension is given in ms, since the time is given in ms.
The C dimension is given in nm, since the wavelength is given in nm.

inputFields.name: x

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.
